Q.title: Between July 1 and July 28, 2024, will the strongest geomagnetic storm have a K-index ("Kp") greater than 6 and less than or equal to 7?
Q.body: This question resolves as the highest Planetary K-index ("Kp") between July 1 and July 28, 2024 (inclusive), according to the German Research Center for Geosciences in their running 30-day history data product.

metadata.background_info:
In May 2024, sunspot region AR3664, now designated as AR3697, returned to face Earth after merging with another active sunspot region, resulting in numerous M- and X-class solar flares that caused intense [geomagnetic storms and auroras](https://earthsky.org/earth/auroras-last-night-extreme-solar-storm-wow-millions-may-10-11-12-2024/) visible at unusually low latitudes. 

As AR3697 [returns to face Earth](https://www.space.com/return-aurora-causing-sunspot-june-solar-storm-prospects) in early June 2024, space weather forecasters anticipate ongoing geomagnetic activity and are closely monitoring the region's continued potential to produce extreme space weather. 

[Sunspots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunspot) are areas of intense magnetic activity that often give rise to solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs), which can disturb Earth's magnetosphere and impact satellite operations, power grids, and navigation systems.

The [K-index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-index), which measures fluctuations in Earth's magnetic field, ranges from from 0 to 9. The NOAA Space Weather Scales uses the Kp values to classify the severity of geomagnetic storms from G1 (minor) to G5 (extreme), equating to Kp values of 5 to 9, respectively.

reasons: The price of silver could be influenced by various environmental factors, including solar activity, which is linked to geomagnetic storms. Strong geomagnetic storms can affect satellite communications and potentially influence market behavior, including commodities like silver.
Investors and traders might be interested in how external factors such as geomagnetic storms could impact commodity prices, including silver, due to potential disruptions in trading or supply chains.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is worth considering due to the potential interrelation between geomagnetic storms and commodity pricing.

P.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
P.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

Q_given_P.title: Given Donald Trump is removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment, will Nvidia's market cap exceed Apple's on June 28, 2024?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. This is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

Then, is it true that on June 28, 2024, the market cap of Nvidia is greater than that of Apple, according to Companies Market Cap, when checked by Metaculus at approximately 4 PM EDT (8 PM UTC)?

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Donald Trump is removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and (2) Nvidia's market capitalization is larger than Apple's on June 28, 2024?
P_and_Q.body:
This question resolves **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

1. **Donald Trump's Ballot Status**: On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. This must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice. The question resolves as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after this date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

2. **Nvidia vs. Apple's Market Capitalization**: On June 28, 2024, the market cap of Nvidia is greater than that of Apple, according to [Companies Market Cap](https://companiesmarketcap.com/), when checked by Metaculus at approximately 4 PM EDT (8 PM UTC).

Both conditions must be satisfied for this question to resolve as "Yes." If either condition is not met, the question resolves as "No."

P.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
P.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.background_info:
*This question is modeled on [this Metaculus question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/18606/trump-removed-or-blocked-from-the-ballot/), but asks instead about the possibility of Trump's removal from primary election ballots.*

The 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution has a section known as the "Disqualification Clause" or Section 3, which may disqualify individuals from holding federal or state office if they have "engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the [U.S.], or given aid or comfort to the enemies thereof." Given the events surrounding the January 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, this section has become a subject of considerable debate with respect to former President Donald Trump's eligibility to run for federal office again.

In New Hampshire, Bryant "Corky" Messner, an attorney who ran for U.S. Senate in 2020 with Trump's endorsement, has [expressed intentions to file a legal challenge](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2023/08/29/trump-14th-amendment-new-hampshire-gop-feuds-as-states-grapple-with-disqualifying-trump-from-ballot/?sh=70038b512e9a) questioning Trump's 2024 candidacy under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The Republican Secretary of State of New Hampshire, David Scanlan, while not actively seeking to remove any candidates, has stated that he will seek legal advice on the issue. Additionally, Michigan’s Democratic Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson has indicated that she will seek a legal opinion on this matter. Voters have also filed lawsuits in Florida and Michigan on the issue. Legal battles are widely expected, and these disputes might reach the U.S. Supreme Court.

This question focuses on whether these and similar ongoing discussions and legal challenges will result in Donald Trump being removed from the primary election ballot of any state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15th, 2024, the planned start of the 2024 Republican National Convention.

Q.title: On June 28th, 2024, will Nvidia's market capitalization be larger than Apple's?
Q.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, on June 28, 2024, the market cap of Nvidia is greater than that of Apple, according to [Companies Market Cap](https://companiesmarketcap.com/), when checked by Metaculus at approximately 4 PM EDT (8 PM UTC).

metadata.background_info:
Since late 2022, Nvidia Corporation has experienced nearly 10x growth in market capitalization, driven by its [dominance in the AI chip market](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/nvidias-ai-chip-dominance-continue-210200974.html). Nvidia's GPUs are critical in the development of large language models, and are highly sought after by major tech companies like OpenAI, Microsoft, Amazon, and Alphabet.

On May 22nd, Nvidia released [impressive Q1 financial results](https://nvidianews.nvidia.com/news/nvidia-announces-financial-results-for-first-quarter-fiscal-2025#:~:text=NVIDIA%20(NASDAQ%3A%20NVDA)%20today,262%25%20from%20a%20year%20ago.) and simultaneously announced a 10:1 stock split and increase to its dividend, sending its stock price to new all-time highs.

reasons: The outcome of Trump's eligibility for the primary election ballot could have significant implications for investor confidence and market dynamics, potentially affecting Nvidia's stock performance and market capitalization.
Political events, such as Trump's legal challenges, may influence market conditions and investor behavior, which could in turn impact tech stocks like Nvidia and their market caps.

Both questions involve high-profile entities (Trump and Nvidia) that are often discussed in the context of market speculation and political influence, making their combination relevant for forecasting.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is worth considering due to the potential interrelatedness of political events and market outcomes.

P.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
P.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

Q_given_P.title: Given the USA wins more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics, will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
Q_given_P.body:
This question combines the outcomes of two separate events:

Suppose the following is true: The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. 

Then, is it true that Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election is greater than 2 points and less than or equal to 3 points on July 15, 2024, as reported by 538 and accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024?

Resolution criteria for the condition: Resolves YES if the USA wins more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.
Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves YES if Trump's lead over Biden is greater than 2 points and less than or equal to 3 points on the specified date according to 538's national polling average.

P_and_Q.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics AND will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
P_and_Q.body: This question resolves Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. (b) Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election is greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 points on July 15, 2024, as reported on the chart for that date and accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead.

P.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
P.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.background_info:
The 2024 Olympic Games is a sporting competition which takes place every four years. It involves a range of different events across multiple sports.

At the Olympic Games, Gold, Silver and Bronze medals are awarded to 1st, 2nd and 3rd place in each event. (In some events two Bronze medals are awarded mostly combat sports).

Q.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.background_info:
On June 27, 2024, Joe Biden and Donald Trump held their first debate as part of the campaign for the 2024 presidential election. Biden's debate performance was [widely seen as poor](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-trump-june-debate-poll/), and prompted calls for Biden to drop out, including [from the New York Times editorial board](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/28/opinion/biden-election-debate-trump.html) and, as of July 5, [three House Democrats](https://thehill.com/homenews/house/4755497-seth-moulton-biden-presidential-race/).

The Biden team has reportedly been [taking action](https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/04/politics/biden-rising-tide-pressure-reelection-bid-analysis/index.html) to reverse recent perceptions, and has [so far insisted](https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4754840-biden-campaign-denies-dropout-rumors/) that Biden will not be dropping out. However, the New York Times [reported](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/03/us/politics/biden-withdraw-election-debate.html) that the Biden team has internally acknowledged that they must turn perceptions around quickly.

According to [538's presidential polling average](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) (when accessed on July 5, 2024), on the date of the debate Trump held a +0.2 percentage point lead in the polling averages, which has since widened to a +2.4 percentage point lead for Trump reported for July 5. The near-term polling trend may be critical as Biden weighs whether to stay in the race ahead of the [2024 Democratic National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention), which is scheduled to be held August 19th through the 22nd.

reasons: Both questions relate to significant events happening in 2024, which could be of interest to the same audience, such as political analysts or sports enthusiasts.
The performance of the USA in the Olympics may influence national sentiment and voter behavior, potentially affecting polling numbers for Trump and Biden.
Both questions involve forecasting future events that are time-sensitive and could be analyzed together for correlations.
relevance.conclusion: It makes sense to consider the logical combination of these questions as they relate to events in the same year and could have overlapping implications.

P.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
P.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August, will USD be worth >= 145 JPY at close on August 9th, 2024?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: Before August 2024, the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that President Biden is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office, causing the Vice President to serve as Acting President. The duration of the incapacity does not matter, and Biden exiting the office by death, resignation, or invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Then, will the USD be worth at least 145 JPY at the close of trading on August 9th, 2024, according to the USD/JPY close listed on Yahoo! Finance?

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 (b) USD is worth >= 145 JPY at close on August 9th, 2024?
P_and_Q.body:
(a) Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024: Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count. Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office.

(b) USD is worth >= 145 JPY at close on August 9th, 2024: Market resolves according to USD/JPY close listed for August 9th, 2024 on Yahoo! Finance.

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

P.title: [Short Fuse] Will the proxy advisor Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) advise Tesla shareholders to vote against Elon Musk's $57 billion package OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk?
P.body: The question will resolve **Yes** if Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) releases a statement explicitly advising Tesla shareholders to vote *against* Elon Musk's pay package at the 2024 Tesla shareholder meeting OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk to the Tesla board of directors. Otherwise the question will resolve as **No**.

Q_given_P.title: Given ISS advises against Musk's package or Kimbal's re-election, will there be a China-Taiwan armed forces death in 2024?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) advises Tesla shareholders to vote against Elon Musk's $57 billion pay package or the re-election of Kimbal Musk at the 2024 Tesla shareholder meeting. Then, before June 6, 2024, will there be a confirmed armed forces conflict death between China and Taiwan? 

Resolution criteria for the condition: The condition is met if ISS releases a statement explicitly advising against either Elon Musk's pay package or Kimbal Musk's re-election. 

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves Yes if credible reports confirm one or more deaths among the armed forces of China or Taiwan as a result of armed conflict between the two parties before June 6th, 2024. Resolves No otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will BOTH of the following occur: (1) ISS advises Tesla shareholders to vote against Musk's package OR Kimbal Musk's re-election (2) Armed forces conflict death between China and Taiwan before June 6, 2024?
P_and_Q.body:
(1) The first condition will resolve as **Yes** if Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) releases a statement explicitly advising Tesla shareholders to vote *against* Elon Musk's pay package at the 2024 Tesla shareholder meeting OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk to the Tesla board of directors. Otherwise, it resolves as **No**.

(2) The second condition will resolve as **Yes** if, before June 6th, 2024, credible reports confirm one or more deaths among the armed forces of China or Taiwan as a result of armed conflict between the two parties. Otherwise, it resolves as **No**.

The combined question will resolve as **Yes** only if both conditions (1) and (2) resolve as **Yes**. Otherwise, it will resolve as **No**.

P.title: [Short Fuse] Will the proxy advisor Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) advise Tesla shareholders to vote against Elon Musk's $57 billion package OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk?
P.body: The question will resolve **Yes** if Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) releases a statement explicitly advising Tesla shareholders to vote *against* Elon Musk's pay package at the 2024 Tesla shareholder meeting OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk to the Tesla board of directors. Otherwise the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.background_info:
Elon Musk is the current CEO of Tesla and owns around 13% of the company. During its founding years in 2003 - 2005, Musk invested heavily into the company, eventually becoming chair of the board of directors and one of the largest shareholders; he subsequently became CEO in October 2008. His success at the company has seen Tesla become the 17th largest company in the world by market cap with its share price soaring since its June 2010 IPO.

As a result of his immense success as CEO, a $56 billion pay package to Musk was approved by Tesla's board of the directors in 2018. However, Musk has yet to receive this package, as per the [FT](https://www.ft.com/content/8d823cef-543a-4d33-afa0-c68f081842d1):

>Tesla’s board has been lobbying investors to re-ratify the $56bn award given in 2018, which was struck down by a Delaware judge in January due to concerns over its size and the independence of the board. In response, Musk vowed to leave the state and move Tesla’s incorporation to Texas.

>Tesla chair Robyn Denholm has argued that Musk deserves to be paid so much because the company hit ambitious targets for revenue and its stock price. She brushed off criticism she is too close to the CEO as “crap”.

Aside from the sheer size of the pay package - the largest of its kind - those who oppose it call into question various decisions made by Musk during his tenure as CEO. In particular,  Musk's social media activity has been called into question, and perhaps most notably the:

- Purchase - and subsequent rebrand - of Twitter (now X) for $44 billion which has attracted a lot of negative criticism and has also seen Musk spend a disproportionate amount of time at that company instead of Tesla.

 - Purchase of $1.5 billion of Bitcoin in 2021 and allowing the cryptocurrency to be used by customers for purchasing Tesla automobiles. The company promptly stopped accepting the currency - causing the price to plummet - after which Tesla announced they had sold almost all of their Bitcoin holdings at a loss.

During significant shareholder votes like this one, influential proxy advisory firms often send out advice to shareholders on what to vote and why. According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proxy_firm):

>A proxy firm provides services to shareholders (in most cases an institutional investor of some type) to vote their shares at shareholder meetings of, usually, listed companies.

The two largest proxy advisory firms are ISS and Glass Lewis. The latter has [advised](https://www.ft.com/content/8d823cef-543a-4d33-afa0-c68f081842d1) shareholders *not* to vote in favour of Musk's package as well as advising shareholders to vote against the re-election of Kimbal Musk - brother of Elon Musk - from the board of directors. The ISS, however, has yet to issue any advice with respect to the June 13 shareholder meeting.

---------------------

See related question:

[*Will a non-Disney-nominated board member be elected to Disney's board at the April 3, 2024, shareholder meeting?*](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/21972/non-disney-board-member-elected-april-2024/)

Q.title: Before June 6, 2024, will there be an armed forces conflict death between China and Taiwan in 2024?
Q.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before June 6th, 2024, credible reports confirm one or more deaths among the armed forces of China or Taiwan as a result of armed conflict between the two parties.

metadata.background_info:
China has escalated military tensions with Taiwan, launching [large-scale military drills](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/22/world/asia/china-taiwan-drills.html) around the island starting on May 23, 2024. These drills were described by China as "punishment" for what it considers separatist acts by Taiwan, and mark a significant test for Taiwan's newly inaugurated leader, [Lai Ching-te](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/5/20/william-lai-ching-te-takes-oath-to-become-taiwans-new-president), who assumed office on May 20, 2024. 

Initial phases of the exercises involved dozens of Chinese fighter jets, destroyers, frigates, and missile speedboats conducting mock strikes against Taiwanese military targets.

reasons: The decisions of ISS regarding Tesla's leadership and compensation may be influenced by broader economic or geopolitical factors, including tensions between China and Taiwan.

Investors and stakeholders in Tesla may be concerned about how geopolitical events, such as a conflict between China and Taiwan, could impact Tesla's operations, market position, and stock performance, which could in turn affect ISS's recommendations.
There may be a general interest in how corporate governance decisions and international conflicts intersect, especially for a high-profile company like Tesla.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential interconnections between corporate governance decisions and geopolitical events, it makes sense to explore the logical combination of these questions.

P.title: Will these AI labs publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024? (Inflection)
P.body: For each AI lab, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

Q_given_P.title: Given Inflection publishes a report on external red-teaming for safety by June 30, 2024, will ISS advise against Musk's package or Kimbal's re-election?
Q_given_P.body:
For Inflection, the condition resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

The outcome resolves **Yes** if Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) releases a statement explicitly advising Tesla shareholders to vote *against* Elon Musk's pay package at the 2024 Tesla shareholder meeting OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk to the Tesla board of directors. Otherwise, the outcome resolves as **No**.

If Inflection does not publish such a report by the specified date, the question resolves as N/A.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Inflection AI lab publishes a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024, and (b) Institutional Shareholder Services advises Tesla shareholders to vote against Elon Musk's $57 billion package or the re-election of Kimbal Musk?
P_and_Q.body: (a) For Inflection AI lab, the question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models. (b) The question resolves **Yes** if Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) releases a statement explicitly advising Tesla shareholders to vote *against* Elon Musk's pay package at the 2024 Tesla shareholder meeting OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk to the Tesla board of directors. Otherwise, the question resolves as **No**.

P.title: Will these AI labs publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024? (Inflection)
P.body: For each AI lab, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.background_info:
On July 21, 2023, the White House announced ([fact sheet](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2023/07/21/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-secures-voluntary-commitments-from-leading-artificial-intelligence-companies-to-manage-the-risks-posed-by-ai/), [full report](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Ensuring-Safe-Secure-and-Trustworthy-AI.pdf)) that Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI have voluntarily committed to manage AI risks.

The voluntary commitments are in three categories (a) "Ensuring Products are Safe Before Introducing Them to the Public", (b) "Building Systems that Put Security First", and (c) "Earning the Public’s Trust", and are "designed to advance a generative AI legal and policy regime".

From [Microsoft](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/openai/concepts/red-teaming), "historically described systematic adversarial attacks for testing security vulnerabilities. With the rise of LLMs, the term has extended beyond traditional cybersecurity and evolved in common usage to describe many kinds of probing, testing, and attacking of AI systems." Note that this question only asks about _safety_, not _security_. [Google](https://bughunters.google.com/about/rules/6625378258649088/google-and-alphabet-vulnerability-reward-program-vrp-rules) and [OpenAI](https://bugcrowd.com/openai) already have bug bounties for security.

- Purchase - and subsequent rebrand - of Twitter (now X) for $44 billion which has attracted a lot of negative criticism and has also seen Musk spend a disproportionate amount of time at that company instead of Tesla.

 - Purchase of $1.5 billion of Bitcoin in 2021 and allowing the cryptocurrency to be used by customers for purchasing Tesla automobiles. The company promptly stopped accepting the currency - causing the price to plummet - after which Tesla announced they had sold almost all of their Bitcoin holdings at a loss.

During significant shareholder votes like this one, influential proxy advisory firms often send out advice to shareholders on what to vote and why. According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proxy_firm):

>A proxy firm provides services to shareholders (in most cases an institutional investor of some type) to vote their shares at shareholder meetings of, usually, listed companies.

The two largest proxy advisory firms are ISS and Glass Lewis. The latter has [advised](https://www.ft.com/content/8d823cef-543a-4d33-afa0-c68f081842d1) shareholders *not* to vote in favour of Musk's package as well as advising shareholders to vote against the re-election of Kimbal Musk - brother of Elon Musk - from the board of directors. The ISS, however, has yet to issue any advice with respect to the June 13 shareholder meeting.

---------------------

See related question:

[*Will a non-Disney-nominated board member be elected to Disney's board at the April 3, 2024, shareholder meeting?*](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/21972/non-disney-board-member-elected-april-2024/)

reasons: Both questions relate to the actions and decisions of influential figures in the tech and finance sectors, which may have interconnected implications for AI safety and corporate governance.
The outcomes of AI safety reports could influence investor sentiment and corporate strategies, potentially affecting shareholder votes and recommendations from advisory firms like ISS.
Stakeholder reactions to AI safety reports might indirectly impact corporate governance decisions, such as those involving Tesla's leadership.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant as they both touch on significant themes of accountability and governance in technology and finance, making it a legitimate inquiry.

P.title: Drake vs Kendrick Lamar: will either artist release another diss track in May?
P.body: The question resolves as **Yes** if either Drake or Kendrick Lamar releases another diss track directly intended for the other artist after May 9, 2024 and before June 1, 2024.

Q_given_P.title: Given Drake or Kendrick Lamar releases a diss track in May, will Inflection launch a mechanism to identify AI-generated content before July 1, 2024?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: Either Drake or Kendrick Lamar releases a diss track directly intended for the other artist after May 9, 2024, and before June 1, 2024. Then, will the AI lab Inflection publicly release a tool to check if some text, audio, or visual content is generated by their AI models before July 1, 2024? 

Resolution criteria for the condition: The question resolves as **Yes** if either Drake or Kendrick Lamar releases another diss track directly intended for the other artist after May 9, 2024, and before June 1, 2024.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves **YES** if Inflection publicly releases a tool to check if some text, audio, or visual content is generated by their AI models before July 1, 2024. Resolves **NO** otherwise. If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Either Drake or Kendrick Lamar releases another diss track intended for the other in May 2024, and (b) Inflection AI lab launches a mechanism to identify AI-generated content before July 1, 2024?
P_and_Q.body: (a) The question resolves as **Yes** if either Drake or Kendrick Lamar releases another diss track directly intended for the other artist after May 9, 2024 and before June 1, 2024. (b) The question resolves as **YES** if Inflection AI lab publicly releases a tool to check if some text, audio, or visual content is generated by their AI models before July 1, 2024.

P.title: Drake vs Kendrick Lamar: will either artist release another diss track in May?
P.body: The question resolves as **Yes** if either Drake or Kendrick Lamar releases another diss track directly intended for the other artist after May 9, 2024 and before June 1, 2024.

metadata.background_info:
Popular rappers Drake and Kendrick Lamar have been publicly feuding after a years-long contempt has bubbled into an all-out war, with each artist leveling enormous unsubstantiated accusations at the other. After the most recent round of the beef, with the release of Kendrick's "Not Like Us" and Drake's "The Heart Part 6", many have speculated that the feud has reached a tipping point and neither artist will release any further music. Do you think it's been played out, or there's more yet?

Further Background: [Wikipedia Drake–Kendrick Lamar feud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drake%E2%80%93Kendrick_Lamar_feud)

Q.title: Will these AI labs launch a mechanism to enable users to understand if content is generated by their AIs before July 1, 2024? (Inflection)
Q.body: For each AI lab, this question resolves as **YES** if the lab publicly releases a tool to check if some text, audio, or visual content is generated by their AI models before July 1, 2024.

metadata.background_info:
On July 21, 2023, the White House announced ([fact sheet](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2023/07/21/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-secures-voluntary-commitments-from-leading-artificial-intelligence-companies-to-manage-the-risks-posed-by-ai/), [full report](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Ensuring-Safe-Secure-and-Trustworthy-AI.pdf)) that Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI have voluntarily committed to manage AI risks.

The voluntary commitments are in three categories (a) "Ensuring Products are Safe Before Introducing Them to the Public", (b) "Building Systems that Put Security First", and (c) "Earning the Public’s Trust", and are "designed to advance a generative AI legal and policy regime".

In this last category, one commitment is to "Develop and deploy mechanisms that enable users to understand if audio or visual content is AI-generated, including robust provenance, watermarking, or both, for AI-generated audio or visual content." This question asks whether this commitment is met in the specified time frame.

OpenAI has [worked on such a watermarking tool](https://techcrunch.com/2022/12/10/openais-attempts-to-watermark-ai-text-hit-limits/), in part devised by computing researcher Scott Aaronson, but has not released such a tool publicly as required for this question.

reasons: Both questions involve predictions about future events that could impact public discourse and media narratives.

The release of diss tracks could influence the cultural environment in which AI tools are developed and perceived, potentially affecting the urgency or focus of AI labs in addressing content generation transparency.
Interest in the music industry and AI technology often overlaps among certain demographics, making the combination relevant for those following both fields.
relevance.conclusion: It makes sense to consider the logical combination of these questions due to the potential interplay between cultural events in music and advancements in AI technology.

P.title: Will Biden drop out before July 20?
P.body: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

Q_given_P.title: Given Biden drops out before July 20, will Russian athletes be barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time. 

Then, will Russian athletes be barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics? 

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves YES if Russian athletes are barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics under either (i) the Russian flag, (ii) The Russian Olympic Committee's flag, or (iii) any other independent or neutral flag, with no more than 34 Russians competing. Resolves NO if more than 34 Russian athletes compete. Resolves ambiguously if the 2024 Olympics are cancelled or postponed to 2025 or afterwards.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden drops out before July 20 and (b) Russian athletes are barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics?
P_and_Q.body: (a) Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time. (b) Russian athletes are barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics under either (i) the Russian flag, (ii) The Russian Olympic Committee's flag, or (iii) any other independent or neutral flag. This will resolve based on the official list of countries and athletes present at the 2024 Olympics or based on credible media reports, indicating that the 2024 Olympics are underway or have concluded without Russian participation. For the question to resolve as **Yes**, no more than 34 Russians can be competing at the 2024 Olympics. If more than 34 Russian athletes compete at the 2024 Olympics, this question will resolve as **No**. If the 2024 Olympics are cancelled or postponed to 2025 or afterwards, this question resolves as ambiguously.

content.text: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

Q.title: Will Russian athletes be barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Russian athletes are barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics under either (i) the Russian flag, (ii) The Russian Olympic Committee's flag, or (iii) any other independent or neutral flag. This will resolve based on the official list of countries and athletes present at the [2024 Olympics](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/paris-2024) or based on credible media reports, indicating that the 2024 Olympics are underway or have concluded without Russian participation. For the question to resolve as **Yes**, no more than 34 Russians can be competing at the 2024 Olympics. 34 was chosen as 10% of [Russian athletes that participated in the 2020 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Olympic_Committee_athletes_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics) to allow for a few individual or sport specific exceptions.

If more than 34 Russian athletes compete at the 2024 Olympics, this question will resolve as **No**.

If the 2024 Olympics are cancelled or postponed to 2025 or afterwards, this question resolves as ambiguously.

metadata.background_info:
After the [Russian's invasion of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine) in February 2022, Russia has been subject to a large amount of international pressure. That pressure has taken many different forms;  [sanctions](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/10266/russia-sanctions-1-year-after-invasion/), [boycotts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_boycott_of_Russia_and_Belarus), protests, oil and gas embargoes, corporate divestment, and more. Many individuals, corporations, and countries have taking action to show international solidarity with Ukraine.

In the sporting world, Russia has been banned from a number of recent international events. On Feb 28th 2022, four days after Russia invaded, FIFA made an unprecedented decision to [ban Russian clubs and the national team from all competitions](https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/mens/worldcup/qatar2022/media-releases/fifa-uefa-suspend-russian-clubs-and-national-teams-from-all-competitions) including the World Cup.

> Football is fully united here and in full solidarity with all the people affected in Ukraine. Both Presidents [FIFA and UEFA] hope that the situation in Ukraine will improve significantly and rapidly so that football can again be a vector for unity and peace amongst people.

In 2023, the IOC (International Olympic Committee) has reiterated their position several times [[1]](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/q-a-on-solidarity-with-ukraine-sanctions-against-russia-and-belarus-and-the-status-of-athletes-from-these-countries)[[2]](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/q-a-on-solidarity-with-ukraine-sanctions-against-russia-and-belarus-and-the-status-of-athletes-from-these-countries) that Russian and Belarusian athletes can only compete as Individual Neutral Athletes.

Despite IOC recommendations Poland banned Russian and Belarusian athletes from [the 2023 European Games](https://notesfrompoland.com/2023/03/29/russians-and-belarusians-banned-from-european-games-in-poland-despite-ioc-recommendations/). In Paris, the 2024 Olympic host city,  event organizers [cancelled a World Cup fencing event](https://apnews.com/article/fencing-france-russia-ukraine-2821983e726628c8bbf21e1eb8dd8c76) after the FIE (International Fencing Federation) [decision](https://apnews.com/article/fencing-russia-ukraine-olympics-9754e17d554df4484c609248019bd1a9) to allow Russian athletes to resume competing one year after the invasion of Ukraine. 

Looking back at previous Olympics, Russia's Track and Field team was [barred from the 2016 Olympics](https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/18/sports/olympics/russia-barred-rio-summer-olympics-doping.html) over a decade long doping scandal. 68 Athletes filled appeals that were ultimately [dismissed by the Court of Arbitration for Sport](https://www.nbcsports.com/bayarea/russians-lose-track-appeal-ioc-weigh-total-ban-rio), though [some](https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1133394/russia-ana-athletics) Russian athletes were able to compete as 'Authorized Neutral Athletes'. At the 2016 Paralympics the entire Russian Paralympic team was banned over the same doping scandal.

reasons: Both questions involve significant events in 2024 that could have broader implications for international relations and public perception.

The political landscape in the US, including Biden's candidacy, might be influenced by international events like the Olympics and the treatment of Russian athletes, which could affect public opinion and voter sentiment.
There may be a perception that Biden's decision to stay in the race could be influenced by global events, including the Olympics, as they relate to US foreign policy and national pride.
relevance.conclusion: It makes sense to consider the logical combination of these questions, as they could be interconnected in terms of political and international dynamics.

P.title: Will these AI labs launch a mechanism to enable users to understand if content is generated by their AIs before July 1, 2024? (Google Deep Mind)
P.body: For each AI lab, this question resolves as **YES** if the lab publicly releases a tool to check if some text, audio, or visual content is generated by their AI models before July 1, 2024.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on Google Deep Mind launching a mechanism for identifying AI-generated content by July 1, 2024, will UCLA hold its in-person graduation ceremonies on June 14, 2024?
Q_given_P.body:
For Google Deep Mind, the condition resolves as **YES** if the lab publicly releases a tool to check if some text, audio, or visual content is generated by their AI models before July 1, 2024.

Suppose the above condition is true. Then, will UCLA hold all three of its main in-person college commencement ceremonies for the graduating Class of 2024 as scheduled for June 14, 2024? This resolves as **Yes** if the ceremonies occur at the Pauley Pavilion, starting within 1 hour of the scheduled times (11 AM, 3 PM, and 7 PM). It resolves as **No** if any ceremony does not meet these criteria, is relocated, or is held entirely online.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Google Deep Mind launches a mechanism to enable users to understand if content is generated by their AIs before July 1, 2024, and (b) UCLA holds its in-person, university-wide graduation commencement ceremonies scheduled for June 14, 2024?
P_and_Q.body:
(a) This question resolves as **YES** if Google Deep Mind publicly releases a tool to check if some text, audio, or visual content is generated by their AI models before July 1, 2024.

(b) This question resolves as **Yes** if the University of California-Los Angeles (UCLA) holds all three of its main in-person college commencement ceremonies for the graduating Class of 2024 scheduled for the following times and locations on June 14, 2024:

- 11 AM at the Pauley Pavilion
- 3 PM at the Pauley Pavilion
- 7 PM at the Pauley Pavilion

The ceremonies must all occur at the specified locations and begin within 1 hour of the scheduled starting time. This question will resolve as **No** if any ceremony either does not begin within an hour of the scheduled time, is moved to another location, or is held entirely online (i.e., without graduates, faculty, and guests attending in person).

On July 21, 2023, the White House announced ([fact sheet](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2023/07/21/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-secures-voluntary-commitments-from-leading-artificial-intelligence-companies-to-manage-the-risks-posed-by-ai/), [full report](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Ensuring-Safe-Secure-and-Trustworthy-AI.pdf)) that Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI have voluntarily committed to manage AI risks.

The voluntary commitments are in three categories (a) "Ensuring Products are Safe Before Introducing Them to the Public", (b) "Building Systems that Put Security First", and (c) "Earning the Public’s Trust", and are "designed to advance a generative AI legal and policy regime".

In this last category, one commitment is to "Develop and deploy mechanisms that enable users to understand if audio or visual content is AI-generated, including robust provenance, watermarking, or both, for AI-generated audio or visual content." This question asks whether this commitment is met in the specified time frame.

OpenAI has [worked on such a watermarking tool](https://techcrunch.com/2022/12/10/openais-attempts-to-watermark-ai-text-hit-limits/), in part devised by computing researcher Scott Aaronson, but has not released such a tool publicly as required for this question.

Q.title: Will UCLA hold its in-person, university-wide graduation commencement ceremonies scheduled for June 14, 2024?
Q.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the University of California-Los Angeles (UCLA) holds all three of its main in-person college commencement ceremonies for the graduating Class of 2024 [scheduled](https://commencement.ucla.edu/schedule/ucla-commencement-schedule-alphabetical#college) for the following times and locations on June 14, 2024:

- 11 AM at the Pauley Pavilion
- 3 PM at the Pauley Pavilion
- 7 PM at the Pauley Pavilion

The ceremonies must all occur at the specified locations and begin within 1 hour of the scheduled starting time. 

This question will resolve as **No** if any ceremony either does not begin within an hour of the scheduled time, is moved to another location, or is held entirely online (i.e., without graduates, faculty, and guests attending in person).

metadata.background_info:
On May 6, 2024, Columbia University [cancelled](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2024/05/06/columbia-commencement-ceremony-protest-live-updates/73583447007/) its main commencement ceremony, opting instead to honor its graduates in 19 smaller ceremonies for each of its colleges. The decision was made in response to pro-Palestinian protests that erupted at the university. 

UCLA has [cancelled in-person classes](https://www.cbsnews.com/losangeles/news/ucla-cancel-in-person-classes-again-after-more-israel-hamas-war-protests/) at its campus, and there has been speculation that it may cancel its main commencement as well. Its fellow southern California school, USC, recently [moved its ceremony](https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2024-05-03/usc-shores-up-campus-limits-access-before-commencement) to the LA Coliseum.

See Also: 

MSN: [Pro-Palestinian Protests Put College Commencements in Jeopardy](https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/pro-palestinian-protests-put-college-commencements-in-jeopardy/ar-BB1lUU4h)

Newsweek: [Full List of Colleges Cancelling Graduation Services Amid Campus Protests](https://www.newsweek.com/columbia-cancels-graduation-ceremony-universities-palestine-protests-1897560)

USA Today: [College graduation canceled due to anti-war protests? It's happened before](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/education/2024/05/07/why-do-colleges-cancel-graduation-a-brief-history/73586349007/)

reasons: Both questions pertain to significant events in 2024 that could impact public perception and trust in institutions, such as AI labs and educational establishments.

The AI lab's release of a mechanism to identify generated content could influence the public's experience and expectations during graduation ceremonies, especially if AI-generated content is involved in the ceremonies.
Understanding the context of AI-generated content could be relevant for attendees of the graduation ceremony, as they may encounter AI-generated materials related to the event.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is interesting as it connects the technological advancements in AI with a major educational event, reflecting on societal implications.

P.title: At the 2024 Olympics, will at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal?
P.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

Q_given_P.title: Given that at the 2024 Olympics, at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal, will the European Union announce new tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: At the 2024 Paris Olympics, 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal, according to credible sources. Then, will the European Union announce new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?

Resolution criteria for the condition: The condition is met if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: The question resolves as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) At the 2024 Olympics, at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal (b) The European Union announces new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
P_and_Q.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) At the Paris 2024 Olympics, 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal, according to credible sources. (2) Before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced new tariffs or duties that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

P.title: At the 2024 Olympics, will at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal?
P.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.background_info:
[Gold medal wins at the Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table) are concentrated in a small number of countries; the United States alone has won nearly 20% of every gold medal ever awarded, and a total of eight countries account for the majority of medalists.

Conversely, prior to the opening of the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris, there are over 100 National Olympic Committees that have never won a gold medal. In recent Games, the number of countries that won their first gold were:

* London 2012: 3
* Rio de Janeiro 2016: 9
* Tokyo 2020: 3

Will this number be 5 or more this year?

Q.title: Will the European Union announce new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
Q.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

metadata.background_info:
On May 14, 2024, the Biden administration imposed [new tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) and other goods](https://apnews.com/article/biden-china-tariffs-electric-vehicles-evs-solar-2024ba735c47e04a50898a88425c5e2c), with the EV tariffs increasing to a total level of 102.5% from the previous total of 27.5%. [Analysts have suggested](https://www.cnn.com/2024/05/15/business/us-tariffs-ev-europe-china-trade/index.html) that the new tariffs may put pressure on the European Union (EU) to protect its own EV industry, as the US tariffs may effectively close off the US market, making the EU market more attractive to Chinese EV manufacturers.

The [European Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Commission) has been [conducting an anti-subsidy investigation of Chinese EVs](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/04/30/chinese-ev-imports-europe-might-need-to-impose-up-to-55percent-in-tariffs-.html) since [September 2023](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/eu-launches-anti-subsidy-investigation-into-chinese-electric-vehicles-2023-09-13/). The [investigation has a July 4 deadline](https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_23_4752) to impose provisional anti-subsidy duties.

reasons: The Olympics often have significant global attention, and the performance of countries can be influenced by economic factors, including trade policies. If the EU imposes tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles, it could affect the economic climate and, in turn, the resources available for countries to invest in their Olympic teams.
Debut gold medals can indicate a shift in competitive balance among nations, which may be influenced by international relations and trade agreements, including those involving tariffs and duties.
There might be a broader interest in how international events like the Olympics and economic policies interact, as both can reflect changing global dynamics.
relevance.conclusion: It makes sense to consider the logical combination of these questions, as there are plausible connections between the outcomes of the Olympics and potential economic policies.

P.title: Will Scotland hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024?
P.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024.  This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect.

It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on Scotland holding an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, will the Prime Minister of France belong to the Together coalition on July 30, 2024?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: Scotland holds a referendum regarding its independence from the United Kingdom before May 3, 2024, and this referendum is official and sanctioned by the UK government, not a "wildcat" or "Catalan" style referendum. Then is it true that the Prime Minister of France will belong to the Together coalition on July 30, 2024?

Resolution criteria for the condition (P): The referendum in Scotland must be held before May 3, 2024, with the consent of the London government.

Resolution criteria for the outcome (Q): The party of the Prime Minister of France must be Together on July 30, 2024, at 12:00 Central European Time, according to credible sources.

If the condition is not met, the question resolves as N/A.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Scotland holds an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, and (2) the Prime Minister of France belongs to the Together coalition on July 30, 2024?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) There is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024. This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect. It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government. (2) The party of the Prime Minister of France is Together on July 30th, at 12:00 Central European Time, according to credible sources.

P.title: Will Scotland hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024?
P.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024.  This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect.

It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government

metadata.background_info:
Scotland is one of the UK’s four constituent nations - and its politics are currently dominated by the [Scottish National Party](https://whatscotlandthinks.org/), a party whose core aim is to remove Scotland from the UK and become an independent country. 

The SNP government in Edinburgh previously successfully negotiated with the UK-wide government for the right to hold a referendum, [which took place in 2014](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Scottish_independence_referendum). The “No” side (“Better Together”) won 55% to 45%. The SNP has, however, won every Scottish national election since that date.

The SNP wish to have a fresh vote - stating that Brexit has changed the terms of the argument. The UK government has, to date, refused to countenance permitting such a vote. Under the Scotland Act, the Edinburgh government does not have the power to hold one [without permission.](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1998/46/section/30)

Q.title: Will the Prime Minister of France belong to the Together coalition on July 30, 2024?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if the party of the Prime Minister of France is Together on July 30th, at 12:00 Central European Time, according to credible sources.

metadata.background_info:
After a far-right victory in the European elections, French President Emmanuel Macron dissolved the National Assembly, calling snap elections for June 30th and July 7th.

The majority of the 577 districts will [see a runoff](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/french-election-run-off-how-does-it-work-what-look-out-2024-07-05/) on Sunday, July 7, with the most common set of qualified parties being the National Rally-led Union of the Far-Right, centrist Together, and left and center-left New Popular Front. The unprecedented number of three-way runoffs (including *four*-ways in five districts) was boosted by strong turnout, [nearly 20 percentage points more than in 2022](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/strong-turnout-france-high-stakes-elections-support-far-right-grows/); but Together and the NPF guided their third-placed candidates to withdraw to improve the other's chances to beat the far-right, mostly represented by Marine Le Pen's National Rally.

Once the runoff numbers are known for the 17th National Assembly, the question becomes: who will be Prime Minister? The French semi-presidential system gives President Macron political responsibilities, in particular in foreign policy, regardless of the makeup of Parliament; but he must also nominate a Prime Minister, who conducts domestic policy. The government does not need a positive confidence vote from legislators, but it could be subject to a vote of no confidence; current Prime Minister Gabriel Attal's minority government has been relying on case-by-case deals to get legislation approved.

While the far-right has already elected 38 Deputies and made it to the runoff almost everywhere, its surge might still be forestalled by the strategic pact between the center and the left.

reasons: The political landscape in the UK, particularly regarding Scotland's independence, may influence the dynamics of French politics, including coalition formations.
Changes in leadership or political alliances in one country can have ripple effects in another, especially within the context of European politics and cooperation.
Both questions pertain to significant political events that could be interconnected in terms of public sentiment and political strategy, making their combination relevant.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is worth considering due to potential interconnections in political dynamics.

P.title: Will an athlete win more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
P.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

Q_given_P.title: GIVEN an athlete wins more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics, will the domestic box office opening of "Deadpool & Wolverine" be higher than that of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" combined?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: At least one athlete wins more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Then, will the domestic box office opening for **Deadpool & Wolverine** be higher than $185,548,391, which is the combined domestic box office opening of **Deadpool** (2016) and **The Wolverine** (2013)?

Resolution criteria for the condition: The condition is met if any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: The outcome resolves as **Yes** if the domestic box office opening for **Deadpool & Wolverine**, as reported by Boxofficemojo, is higher than $185,548,391.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) An athlete wins more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics (2) The domestic box office opening of "Deadpool & Wolverine" is higher than that of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" combined?
P_and_Q.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics. (2) The domestic box office opening for "Deadpool & Wolverine" reported by Boxofficemojo on the movie's page is higher than $185,548,391, which is the sum of the box office openings for "Deadpool" (2016) and "The Wolverine" (2013).

P.title: Will an athlete win more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
P.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

metadata.background_info: [Tennis at the Olympics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2024_Summer_Olympics) has five events: singles for men and women, and doubles for men, women and mixed. This makes it possible for the same athlete to win more than one medal. Will it happen?

Q.title: Will the domestic box office opening of "Deadpool & Wolverine" be higher than that of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" combined?
Q.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the domestic box office opening for the **Deadpool & Wolverine** reported by Boxofficemojo on the [movie's page](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt6263850/?ref_=bo_se_r_1) is higher than $185,548,391 which is the sum of the box openings for **Deadpool** (2016) and **The Wolverine** (2013): $132,434,639 + $53,113,752.

metadata.background_info:
**Deadpool & Wolverine** is an upcoming blockbuster by Marvel Studios scheduled to be released on July 26, 2024 featuring the two iconic heroes from the X-Men Universe.

The recent projection from Deadline puts the domestic opening to [$160-$165 million](https://deadline.com/2024/07/deadpool-wolverine-box-office-opening-projection-1236000799/), which would not only be the best opening year-to-date (beating **Inside Out 2** with $154 million) but also a record start for an R-rated movie. 

Another projection from June was even higher, [at $200+ million](https://deadline.com/2024/06/deadpool-wolverine-box-office-projection-1235973545/).

The ticket seller Fandango [reported on May 21](https://www.gamespot.com/articles/deadpool-and-wolverine-has-strongest-day-one-ticket-pre-sales-in-franchise-history-at-fandango/1100-6523599/) that their ticket pre-sales for the movie were the site's biggest ones in 2024 up to date.

reasons: Both questions involve events occurring in 2024, making them relevant in a temporal sense.
The performance of the movie could be influenced by the overall cultural interest in the Olympics, including tennis events, which might affect audience turnout for the film.
Athletes participating in the Olympics often have significant media coverage, which could also impact the marketing and reception of films released around the same time.
relevance.conclusion: It makes sense to consider the logical combination of these questions as they could be interrelated in the context of events happening in 2024.

P.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
P.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on 538 projecting Biden as the favorite on July 19, will Rishi Sunak fail to be elected in the 2024 UK General Election?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: On July 19, 2024, Joe Biden is projected by FiveThirtyEight to have a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast. The resolution source for this condition is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this condition is considered 50-50.

Given this, will Rishi Sunak fail to be elected as a Member of Parliament in the July 4, 2024 UK general election? This question resolves as **Yes** if for any reason Rishi Sunak fails to be elected as a Member of Parliament in the July 4, 2024 UK general election. If Sunak is elected as a Member of Parliament for any constituency in the July 4, 2024 UK general election, this question will resolve as **No**.

Resolution should cite credible media reports, or an official announcement from the returning officer of the constituency in which Sunak is a candidate (if he is a candidate in any constituency).

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden is projected as the favorite by FiveThirtyEight on July 19, 2024, and (b) Rishi Sunak fails to be elected as an MP in the July 4, 2024 UK General Election?
P_and_Q.body:
(a) Joe Biden is projected as the favorite by FiveThirtyEight on July 19, 2024. This will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for July 19, 2024. This will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this will resolve 50-50. The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19. Changes in methodology by FiveThirtyEight will not affect resolution. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, it will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19. Note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark. The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

(b) Rishi Sunak fails to be elected as a Member of Parliament in the July 4, 2024 UK general election. This resolves as **Yes** if for any reason Rishi Sunak fails to be elected as a Member of Parliament in the July 4, 2024 UK general election. If Sunak is elected as a Member of Parliament for any constituency in the July 4 2024 UK general election, this resolves as **No**. Resolution should cite credible media reports, or an official announcement from the returning officer of the constituency in which Sunak is a candidate (if he is a candidate in any constituency).

Q.title: Will Rishi Sunak fail to be elected in the 2024 UK General Election?
Q.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if for any reason Rishi Sunak fails to be elected as a Member of Parliament in the July 4 2024 UK general election.

If Sunak is elected as a Member of Parliament for any constituency in the July 4 2024 UK general election, this question will resolve as **No**.

Resolution should cite [credible](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) media reports, or an official announcement from the returning officer of the constituency in which Sunak is a candidate (if he is a candidate in any constituency).

metadata.background_info:
[Rishi Sunak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rishi_Sunak?useskin=vector), born 12 May 1980, is a British politician who has served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and Leader of the Conservative Party since 2022. Sunak has been Member of Parliament for [Richmond (Yorks)](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Richmond_(Yorks)_(UK_Parliament_constituency)&useskin=vector) since 2015.

In the most recent general election in 2019, [Sunak won his seat](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Richmond_(Yorks)_(UK_Parliament_constituency)&useskin=vector#Elections_in_the_2010s) with 63.6% of the vote; the nearest competitor was the Labour Party candidate on 16.4% of the vote. 

Since 2019 the Conservative Party, in power since 2010, has seen a significant decline in its support according to [opinion polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_United_Kingdom_general_election?useskin=vector#Graphical_summary); and as of late May 2024, it trails the opposition Labour Party by around 20 points. 

[Sunak's personal approval rating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leadership_approval_opinion_polling_for_the_2024_United_Kingdom_general_election?useskin=vector) has been in negative territory for nearly his entire tenure as Prime Minister, and is [among the worst for any British Conservative or Labour leader](https://www.ipsos.com/en-uk/rishi-sunaks-satisfaction-falls-equal-worst-ever-ipsos-rating-conservative-or-labour-leader) in Ipsos data going back to 1978.

In May 2024 [Sunak called a snap general election](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-69050450), to be held on July 4.

Sunak is expected to contest the constituency of [Richmond and Northallerton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richmond_and_Northallerton_(UK_Parliament_constituency)?useskin=vector) in the July 4 election, which was created following the [2023 Periodic Review of Westminster constituencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Periodic_Review_of_Westminster_constituencies?useskin=vector).

reasons: Both questions pertain to political events in 2024, which may be influenced by each other; for example, the outcome of Biden's forecast could affect public opinion about UK elections and vice versa.
Political analysts may be interested in understanding how election outcomes in one country can impact perceptions and forecasts in another, especially in a globalized context.

The performance of major political figures like Biden and Sunak can create narratives that affect voter sentiment and behavior, making the combination of these questions relevant for comprehensive political analysis.
relevance.conclusion: It makes sense to consider the logical combination of these questions due to their interconnectedness in the political landscape of 2024.

P.title: Will "Twisters" (2024) have a Rotten Tomatoes critics score of at least 75%? ("Certified Fresh")
P.body:
"Twisters" (2024) Rotten Tomatoes page

This resolves YES if the Tomatometer score is 75% or higher, one week after release (July 26th). 

Details 

I will use whatever precision is listed by Rotten Tomatoes (typically an integer percentage, no decimal).

For example, the original "Twister" (1996) currently has a Tomatometer of 63%. This is the equivalent score I will use.

"Certified Fresh" is just used for illustrative purposes (AFAIK, it requires >=75% Tomatometer, but there might be other restrictions—the market resolves solely based on the displayed score).

"Twisters" (2024) is a standalone sequel to the 1996 original, directed by Lee Isaac Chung ("Minari"), starring Glen Powell ("Top Gun: Maverick") and Daisy Edgar Jones ("Normal People").
